body: ## New career services professional onboarding  Career services professionals across campus have created a modular onboarding training for new career services professionals. This will allow for new career services staff members to be scheduled into 11 meetings with their new colleagues around campus to learn about the minimum expectations for career services professionals within seven functional areas, as recently developed by the career services directors:   ### Scheduling trainings  Once a new career services professional begins their role, either the new professional or the director should complete the form below to schedule the modular trainings. After this form has been submitted, the new professional will be scheduled with their new colleagues around campus to begin their trainings.  Complete this form to schedule trainings  [Complete this form to schedule trainings](https://iu.co1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_4T5iFUXH9x9a27X)  If you have any questions about the training process, please contact Campus Career and Advising Services staff at ccas@iupui.edu .

## Join us for Recruit IUPUI!  Did you know that over 90% of IUPUI's students remain in the state of Indiana after graduation? And that one-third of those students are first generation college students? Are you prepared to effectively recruit from this large talent pool?  The IUPUI Career Services Council annually hosts the Recruit IUPUI event, an afternoon of professional development designed with you in mind. This is not a career fair , but an opportunity for you to network with career services offices, learn about unique ways to engage with IUPUI, and identify best strategies for recruiting IUPUI students and alums for your internship, part-time, and full-time opportunities.  At Recruit IUPUI , you'll learn about and experience:  Unfortunately, due to the COVID-19 situation, we were unable to host the event in 2020. We invite you to view short presentations prepared by participating IUPUI staff that cover topics that include:  View presentations  [View presentations](https://indiana.sharepoint.com/:f:/s/msteams_92d57a/EuEeBHzbZglFjVm4zum6MDwB6T1P38uXVXfFvTrCCTYTjw?e=DgXvc2)

## Grow your network  IUPUI's network of over 20 career services offices and professionals helps you personalize a recruitment strategy to target specific groups of students and alumni. IUPUI's Career Services Council allows career professionals to share resources and to offer a variety of career fairs and events. With your involvement, we help students and alumni explore, select, prepare for, and pursue their career goals.  Employer and community partnerships are vital to the success of our career events, and we hope you will participate! Grow your connection with IUPUI by engaging students, recruiting talent, and sponsoring various career programs. Key events for this academic year are listed below. Click on the links for event details, including registration information.   ### Recruiting opportunities  IU Luddy Indianapolis IT, Data, Design, and Digital Media Spring Career Fair (Virtual)  [IU Luddy Indianapolis IT, Data, Design, and Digital Media Spring Career Fair (Virtual)](https://events.iu.edu/live/events/1217605-iu-luddy-indianapolis-it-data-design-and-digital)  Friday, February 16, 2024  Starts at 12 p.m.  Handshake  -  Luddy Indianapolis Virtual Spring Career Fair  View the full calendar  [View the full calendar](https://events.iu.edu/iupuicareer/)

IUPUI has joined Handshake for our campus jobs management system that includes most schools on campus. You will also be able to see career-related events shared by the campus and approved external organizations.  If you would like to gain access to view the jobs and events available to students in your school, please complete the registration found at the link below where you will create a student/alumni account. Please select the option in the top right corner that states "No account? Sign up here."  Once your account is approved, do not use the SSO option to log in. Instead, click on the log in option below that states: "You can also sign in with your email address."  If you are also a current student at another IU campus, you will need to use a different email address. If you are registered for classes using your @iu.edu email address, you will need to use your @iupui.edu email address to register for a Handshake account at IUPUI.  If you hire students and will be posting opportunities as an employer in Handshake, we recommend you use a personal email address to create your student account.  Register for access to Handshake.  [Handshake.](https://iupui.joinhandshake.com)

## Program overview   ### Our vision  Promote undergraduate student success through a high-quality sophomore-level internship program that engages with Indianapolis employers.   ### Our mission  To foster undergraduate student success through high-quality internships sparking goal setting, career exploration, and connecting academics to professional work with local Indianapolis employers.   ### Program outcomes   #### Skills  The intern will demonstrate career-related skills.   #### Goals  The intern will explain and analyze their career goals and personal goals for growth.   #### Identity  The intern will recognize their professional identity and how it fits into future plans.   ### Our story  The Sophomore Internship Program (SIP) was developed for sophomore IUPUI students interested in a paid, off-campus internship. Current participants represent 20 majors across 10 schools and academic units on the IUPUI campus. SIP is a campuswide collaboration that encourages students to connect with professionals in the Indianapolis area. To date, over 100 IUPUI students have been successfully placed in internships from our program.    The Sophomore Internship Program at IUPUI is generously supported by Citizens Energy Group, Duke Energy, and New Skills Ready Network.   ### Our history  The Sophomore Internship Program began in 2017 with a charitable donation from Duke Energy Group to the IU Foundation for internships at IUPUI. Under the directorship of Campus Career and Advising Services, the first full group of 10 interns started in the 2017–18 academic year. Beginning in 2019, Citizens Energy Group partnered with SIP to offer more internship opportunities for IUPUI students.

## First Destination Survey   ### Career outcomes for IUPUI undergraduates  In coordination with the Career Services Council’s Research and Assessment Committee, Campus Career and Advising Services administers the First Destination Survey to all IUPUI undergraduates who earn a certificate, associate degree, or bachelor’s degree.  This survey is based on the National Association of Colleges and Employers (NACE) standards and protocols developed to standardize collection of career outcomes data. IUPUI Institutional Research and Decision Support provides support in creating and maintaining the interactive Tableau dashboards below.  [National Association of Colleges and Employers (NACE) standards and protocols](http://www.naceweb.org/job-market/graduate-outcomes/first-destination/standards-and-protocols/)  Graduates can complete the survey at go.iupui.edu/nextstep .  [go.iupui.edu/nextstep](http://go.iupui.edu/nextstep)   ### Most recent career outcomes*  90.0% of graduates reported positive career outcomes with employment or further education, and 59.4% reported full-time employment.   #### Career outcomes by school and by major  Explore our career outcomes dashboard to see the various career outcomes of our graduates by school and by major. Choose the 2022 Graduate Cohort to see the latest data.   ####  Career outcomes by school/major dashboard  [Career outcomes by school/major dashboard](https://tableau.bi.iu.edu/t/prd/views/FirstDestination2016/CareerOutcomesGroup?iframeSizedToWindow=true&%3Aembed=y&%3AshowAppBanner=false&%3Adisplay_count=no&%3AshowVizHome=no#1#1)   ##### Majors most likely to have a full-time job   #### Majors most likely to pursue further education     #### Salaries by school and by major  Explore our salary dashboard to see the starting salaries of our full-time employed graduates by school and by major. Choose the 2022 Graduate Cohort to see the latest data.   ####  Starting salaries by school/major dashboard  [Starting salaries by school/major dashboard](https://tableau.bi.iu.edu/t/prd/views/FirstDestination2016/SalaryGroups?iframeSizedToWindow=true&%3Aembed=y&%3AshowAppBanner=false&%3Adisplay_count=no&%3AshowVizHome=no#1#1#1)   ##### Majors with highest average starting salaries (limited to majors with at least 10 graduates reporting salaries)   ##### Salary negotiation  To further explore salary differences across demographic backgrounds, the Career Services Council added a question on salary negotiation to the 2022 survey:  Was this the first salary you were offered?  Summary of analyses  67.7% of all graduates who responded to the negotiation question ( N = 811) accepted the first salary they were offered without negotiating. That is, only 33.2% of respondents negotiated. Of those who negotiated, 56.9% were successful.   #### Employers and locations of employment  Explore our employers dashboard to see the employers and locations of employment for our full-time employed graduates by school and by major. Choose the 2022 Graduate Cohort to see the latest data.   ####  Employers/location of employment by school/major dashboard  [Employers/location of employment by school/major dashboard](https://tableau.bi.iu.edu/t/prd/views/FirstDestination2016/EmployerLocation1?iframeSizedToWindow=true&%3Aembed=y&%3AshowAppBanner=false&%3Adisplay_count=no&%3AshowVizHome=no#4#1)  88.0% of full-time employed graduates are employed in Indiana, 61.0% in Indianapolis specifically.   #### Relationship of job to major  Explore our position relationship to major dashboard to see the percentages of our full-time employed graduates reporting that their job is related to their major. Choose the 2022 Graduate Cohort to see the latest data.   ####  Position relationship to major dashboard  [Position relationship to major dashboard](https://tableau.bi.iu.edu/t/prd/views/FirstDestination2016/PosRelGrp?iframeSizedToWindow=true&%3Aembed=y&%3AshowAppBanner=false&%3Adisplay_count=no&%3AshowVizHome=no#1#1#1)  83.9% of full-time employed graduates report their position is related to their field of study.   ##### In all schools, the majority of respondents report working in a related field.   #### Further education  Explore our further education dashboard to see the institutions and fields of study for graduates who are continuing their education. Choose the 2022 Graduate Cohort to see the latest data.   ###  Further education dashboard  [Further education dashboard](https://tableau.bi.iu.edu/t/prd/views/FirstDestination2016/FurtherEduc?iframeSizedToWindow=true&%3Aembed=y&%3AshowAppBanner=false&%3Adisplay_count=no&%3AshowVizHome=no#1#1)   #### Debt and repayment confidence  Explore our debt and repayment dashboard to see the levels of debt our graduates incur and their levels of confidence in repaying their debt on time. Choose the 2022 Graduate Cohort to see the latest data.   ###  Debt and repayment dashboard  [Debt and repayment dashboard](https://tableau.bi.iu.edu/t/prd/views/FirstDestination2016/DebtGroup?iframeSizedToWindow=true&%3Aembed=y&%3AshowAppBanner=false&%3Adisplay_count=no&%3AshowVizHome=no#1#1)  55.6% of graduates report holding no student loan debt; 35.6% report holding less than $50,000 in debt.  69.4% of graduates who hold loan debt report that they are very confident or somewhat confident in their ability to repay their loans on time.   #### Internship participation  Explore our internship participation dashboard to see the rates at which our graduates participate in practical work and learn opportunities. Choose the 2022 Graduate Cohort to see the latest data.  Internship participation dashboard  [Internship participation dashboard](https://tableau.bi.iu.edu/t/prd/views/FirstDestination2016/InternshipParticipateSatis?iframeSizedToWindow=true&%3Aembed=y&%3AshowAppBanner=false&%3Adisplay_count=no&%3AshowVizHome=no#1)  61.0% of graduates completed at least one internship, practicum, co-op, student teaching, or clinical placement.  35.2% of those graduates (who had an internship) reported an internship leading to a full-time offer.  93.5% agreed the internship completed their degree and helped prepare them for a career.  *Most recent data come from the 2022 cohort (graduated July 2021 through June 2022; data collected through December 2022) and are based on a 42.2% knowledge rate.   ### Questions or comments?  If you have questions or comments about the IUPUI First Destination Survey, please address them to Campus Career and Advising Services .  [Campus Career and Advising Services](https://ccas.iupui.edu/contact/index.html)

## Overview of the application questions  There are four questions on the application. The first question helps us with matching. The remainder will help us get to know you, as well as help you prepare for interviews and prompted reflections during the semester.  Please note: The rubric on each question is a guide to help you write your best response. They are not used as a scoring mechanism.   ### Question #1   #### Why did you choose each internship site/position you selected? Give specific examples or explanations of how each one you chose would help you reach your goals or how it will be used to explore career options.  Do you see a common theme to why you chose the sites, or do you have very different reasons for each? How will an internship at each site fit into your goals? Tell us a little about each site/position you selected and how having that internship will help you learn and grow.  Do you see a common theme to why you chose the sites, or do you have very different reasons for each? How will an internship at each site fit into your goals? Tell us a little about each site/position you selected and how having that internship will help you learn and grow.   #### Excellent   #### Good  Makes some connections between selected internship positions and goals or how it will be used to explore options.   #### Poor   ### Question #2   #### What transferable skills and strengths can you contribute to the internships you listed above? Give at least two examples of transferable skills and experiences gained to date and how those fit with an internship.  Consider skills you’ve gathered during coursework, class projects, prior work or volunteer experiences, or leadership activities. Be sure to highlight skills and experiences that might relate to the sites you chose, or that can help you be a successful team member at that site. Check out the IUPUI’s Profiles of Learning for Undergraduate Success for some guidance on what skills IUPUI wants you to start developing as an undergraduate student. What goals would you like to accomplish from participating in these activities and requirements? Give specific examples and explanations of the program’s activities would help you with your bigger plans and next steps or exploration of career options.  By taking part in SIP, you are agreeing to participate in our required activities and reflections. ## Get help with your application   ### Meet with us  Before the application goes live, you can attend information sessions to learn more about our program. Information sessions take place in the two weeks before the application opens. Sign up for information sessions when times are available on SAS. Once the application is live, you can schedule an appointment with us to review your application before submitting.  The SIP team offers in-person and virtual appointments. These appointments are available Monday–Friday . We do offer drop-ins, which are posted on SAS. To schedule an appointment, complete the following steps:  [Student Appointment Scheduler (SAS)](https://sisjee.iu.edu/essweb-prd/web/sas/student/init/)  Please note: We do not assist with creating resumes. Once you have visited your career services office or the Office of Student Employment for assistance, you can schedule an appointment to receive feedback on your resume.  [your career services office](https://career.iupui.edu/students-alumni/career-services/index.html)  [Office of Student Employment](https://employment.iupui.edu/)   ### Information sessions  The recordings below are from an information session held in spring 2022. Much of the content within these videos is the same, like the application and interview process. However, our program requirements have changed since these were recorded. In addition, they have an online document review process where students may submit their documents for online review. ## Graduate with experience  The Sophomore Internship Program (SIP) provides students with an opportunity to apply their academic coursework in a paid internship experience. Students are placed in professional internships with local industry partners. This program targets sophomore students of all majors and provides supportive services throughout the application process and internship experience.  [Sign up for more information Sign up to receive more information about our program](https://iu.co1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_3meCNWKtusPxgR7?origin=pwe-sip)   ### Sign up for more information  Sign up to receive more information about our program   ### What is SIP?  Each semester, SIP has a cohort of up to 20 students at 10–20 different internship sites. We’ve had students from a variety of different majors. Interns are required to complete program objectives, such as written reflections, site visits, and an e-Portfolio, to enhance their internship experience.  Through your work at the internship site and our program’s initiatives, you will:  Many interns have the opportunity to stay at their site as a part-time job until graduation. Even if you decide to move on from your site, you will be equipped with the skills necessary to pursue exciting opportunities. ## Who can be a professional reference?  Our application requires two professional references that can speak on your work and professionalism. References do not have to be from paid opportunities (for example, a supervisor from a long-term volunteer experience could be applicable).  It is common practice to ask your contacts before listing them as a reference. We do ask you choose how you know your contact. If you don't see a relevant option, reconsider if this person can speak to your professional work.   ## Professor/staff member  As a student, professors and staff on campus might be the best indication of your work ethic and experience. Get to know your professors and the staff on campus, whether this be through classroom or program experiences. It's their job to give references for students—just make sure you ask first.   ## Academic or career advisor  Your academic or career advisor probably has a good idea of who you are, especially if you keep in frequent contact with them. As with faculty and staff, most advisors are willing to serve as a reference if asked.   ## Coworker/supervisor  Coworkers and supervisors at current or previous jobs—as well as long-term volunteer experiences—can speak to your work. These are great references! Remember to ask permission before listing them as a reference. In addition, keep them updated on what positions you are applying for to avoid surprises when they get emails or phone calls.   ## Other  Use extreme caution on selecting "other"—just because it's an option doesn't mean you should choose it. If you have a strong professional reference that doesn't quite fit in the other categories, put it here. This does not mean your family, friends, or religious leaders (unless you worked directly for one, then list that under coworker/supervisor).  You might be tempted to list high school teachers or other references from high school. These aren't the best references now that you are in college. We understand some of you are freshmen and have had limited time to develop a connection with the IUPUI community. Many first-year professors and advisors are happy to serve as a reference for now. You can replace them later as you grow your network.   ### Reminder  Finding professional references is an important part of job and internship applications. We advise picking people who can speak to your capabilities and success in a work capacity (does not have to be paid work).  You must ask people before listing them as a reference. Many will agree to do so, but need the heads-up to prepare for the phone call or email.  Still have questions? A career services professional can help you determine who would be best on a case-by-case basis.

## Employers recruiting at IUPUI  The IUPUI Career Services Council is committed to working in the best interest of IUPUI students. The IUPUI Career Services Council has established the following recruiting policies and procedures to assist recruiters in connecting with our students and alumni in a fair, ethical, and legal manner. We reserve the right to refuse job postings and virtual or on-campus recruiting requests at our discretion.  The Career Services Council (CSC) invites employers and organizations to use our services provided they meet the following criteria:  [Principles for Employment Professionals](http://www.naceweb.org/principles/?referal=knowledgecenter&amp%3BmenuID=203)  [Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) l](http://www.eeoc.gov/employers/index.cfm)  [Fair](https://www.dol.gov/whd/regs/compliance/hrg.htm)  [Labor Standards Act (FLSA).](https://www.dol.gov/whd/regs/compliance/hrg.htm)  [Fact Sheet #71: Internship Programs Under The Fair Labor Standards](https://www.dol.gov/whd/regs/compliance/whdfs71.htm)  [Act.](https://www.dol.gov/whd/regs/compliance/whdfs71.htm)  In addition to these legal and ethical guidelines, the following recruiting practices will NOT be allowed:  EMPLOYER PROCEDURES FOR ON-CAMPUS or VIRTUAL RECRUITING  [contact the school directly](https://career.iupui.edu/employers/school-specific-career-offices/index.html)  [https://recruiting.iupui.edu](https://recruiting.iupui.edu)  [(http://international.iupui.edu/).](http://international.iupui.edu/)  POSTING JOBS AT IUPUI  [Handshake.](https://iupui.joinhandshake.com/)  RESUME REFERRALS  IUPUI does not release resumes to employers without student consent. Employers can download resumes via Handshake for all students who have uploaded a resume and interacted with the company via applying to a job or interview schedule, RSVPing for an employer hosted event, or signing up for a session with the employer at a virtual fair.  SERVICES PROVIDED TO THIRD PARTY AGENCIES  IUPUI Career Services offices define third-party recruiters as agencies, organizations, or individuals recruiting candidates for temporary, part-time, or full-time employment opportunities for other organizations rather than for internal positions. This includes entities that make referrals or recruit for profit or not for profit, and it includes agencies that collect student information to be disclosed to employers for purposes of recruitment and employment. Examples are employment agencies, search firms, contract recruiters, venture capital firms acting on behalf of their portfolio companies, and online job posting or resume referral services.  Third-party recruiters may utilize Career Center job listing services, participate in on-campus recruiting, and attend select career fairs. They will be required to verify in advance whether they are recruiting for their own organizations or for their clients. Third-party firms who are recruiting for positions within their own organizations must clearly differentiate those opportunities from their client engagements. Failure to abide by these third-party requirements will result in loss of access to IUPUI Career Services.  Third-party recruiters representing client organizations must:

## Apply to SIP  Join our group of interns and work on a professional team with an organization in the Indianapolis area. You'll work up to 15 hours per week during the school semester. You'll have the opportunity to immerse yourself in an experience, choosing from a variety of positions offered every semester. This is also a great way to grow your professional network.  IUPUI students are increasingly diverse across multiple identities, and SIP has a great opportunity and responsibility to ensure that future Indianapolis professionals represent the communities they serve. We encourage applicants of racial and ethnic-minority backgrounds typically underrepresented in any major and those who are the first in their family to attend college.   ### Program qualifications   #### Freshman or first-year student  Current freshman-level undergraduate students (under 30 credit hours) are eligible to apply for our program if they will reach sophomore-level credit hours (at least 30) the semester after they apply.  Current first-year undergraduate students are eligible to apply for our program the second semester of their first year at IUPUI.   #### Sophomore or second-year student  Current sophomore-level undergraduate students are eligible to apply for our program if they will not reach junior-level credit hours (more than 59) the semester after they apply.  Current second-year undergraduate students are eligible to apply for our program the first semester of their second year at IUPUI.   #### Full-time IUPUI student  This program is for IUPUI undergraduate students only, and you must be enrolled as a full-time student (more than 12 credit hours per semester). Transfer students are eligible after completing at least one semester at IUPUI.   #### GPA eligibility  We require a minimum GPA of 2.0.  Your coursework comes first, and we don't want to affect your grades. Beyond clearing the minimum requirement, there are no bonus points for higher GPAs. Transfer students must have an IUPUI GPA.   #### Schedule availability  You'll need to commit to 10–15 hours per week for working at an internship site.  Some sites are flexible, but you can expect to need about 10 hours a week, Monday through Friday, to gain the maximum benefit from your experience.  We do not have summer positions available.   #### Priority group eligibility  We require that students must be a member of one or more priority groups:   ### About the application  Students interested in SIP must submit an application, much like any other job or internship. The application requires you to log in with your IU credentials. We strongly encourage students to work with the career services office in their school or the Office of Student Employment for the application process.  While our application is not currently open, you can scroll down to view the components of the application to prepare in advance.  Sign up for more information  [Sign up for more information](https://iu.co1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_3meCNWKtusPxgR7?origin=pwe-sip)   ### Application help  The application is completed through Qualtrics and requires the four components below. We recommend reviewing the components and preparing your answers before starting the application.   ##### Resume  We screen your resume to ensure it contains relevant information an employer will need to know (such as your education and experience). If you're selected to move on to the interview phase, employers will review your resume to prepare for meeting you. Therefore, it’s highly important that you have a polished resume. We strongly encourage students to visit a career services professional for resume assistance.  Visit career services  [Visit career services](https://career.iupui.edu/students-alumni/career-services/index.html)   ##### Short-answer essay questions  There are four questions on the application; the first of which helps us with matching. The other questions allow us to get to know you and prepare you for potential interviews.  See the questions here   ##### Professional references  SIP requires two professional references. Often, applications will require professional contacts or letters of recommendation. We do not ask for letters of recommendation— only two professional references. Please inform your references that our team will reach out to them shortly after the application deadline.  Learn who and how to ask   ##### List of internship rankings  Rank your top three or four choices. We recommend reading the position postings thoroughly to have a clear understanding of the internship. Be mindful that you will be responsible for transportation to and from the site.  View past internships  [View past internships](https://indiana.sharepoint.com/:b:/s/msteams_d37d28/EaLy-epOuIlCkc3G7EV8pBwBgNbdl9xSaCEjLDp6nG_Img?e=azoIV2)  Need more help? Meet with a Sophomore Internship Program representative or schedule an appointment with your career services.   ##### Meet with us  Schedule an appointment with us to get answers to your questions or to learn more about being an SIP intern.  [Meet with career services For application material help, meet with the career services office in your school or the Office of Student Employment.](https://career.iupui.edu/students-alumni/internships/sophomore-internship-program/apply/get-help.html#meetCareerServices)   ##### Meet with career services  For application material help, meet with the career services office in your school or the Office of Student Employment.   ### After you submit your application  After you apply to SIP, we'll send a timeline of when you can expect to hear back on next steps. We include very specific dates, so you don't need to follow up. We don't review applications until after the due date, and we'll tell you the date when you can expect to hear back. There's no need to follow up with us—we'll keep you posted!  If you submit an application and don't receive a confirmation email immediately, check the junk mail of the email address you included on the application. Still don't see it? Email us , and we'll confirm whether or not we have it.   ### Interview information  If you move on to the interviews, you'll have individual interviews with the different sites you are matched with. We'll provide guidance on how to be successful in the interviews. We do not give more information at this point because students tend to get overwhelmed.  Further information will be given to you in detail upon acceptance into the interview stage. U ntil then, please be patient and good luck with your application!

## About internships  An internship is academically recognized, experiential learning that integrates knowledge and theory learned in the classroom with practical application and skills development in a professional setting. Internships provide opportunities:   ### Internship contacts and courses   ### You need an internship  If you want to be competitive for full-time employment after completing your IUPUI degree, you will need to complete at least one internship during college. Data from our IUPUI First Destination Survey show that graduates who completed an internship were significantly less likely to still be seeking employment after graduation and even reported significantly higher starting salaries!   ### Find internships on Handshake  Currently enrolled students already have an account created for them on the IUI Handshake platform. There are thousands of internship opportunities that you can view and apply for located both locally and from across the country. You can even find fully remote internships.  [IUI Handshake](https://iupui.joinhandshake.com)  With so many internships in one place, it can be challenging to find the ones you want. Completing your Handshake profile will allow the platform to better suggest internships that will interest you. When searching for internships on the platform, make sure and take advantage of the search filters and keyword searching they provide. The article and short video at the following link will help you make the most of searching for internships on Handshake. How To Search For Jobs On Handshake  [How To Search For Jobs On Handshake](https://joinhandshake.com/blog/students/how-to-search-for-jobs-on-handshake/)   ### Work and Learn Indiana  Work and Learn Indiana has internship postings from throughout the state of Indiana, some of which are eligible for the EARN Indiana program (a state work-study program). Thanks to a collaboration with Work and Learn Indiana, these postings now appear in the IUPUI Handshake platform. When students click through a Work and Learn position on Handshake to the Work and Learn Indiana website to apply, they will need to create a separate account there.   ### The Life-Health Sciences Internship Program  The Life-Health Sciences Internship Program connects IUPUI life and health sciences undergraduates with research and professional experience internships on and near campus. Interns explore and refine career and academic goals, gain valuable skills, and grow as professionals under the supervision of faculty and staff in IUPUI graduate and professional programs. Internships are paid and last from the end of August until the beginning of May.  [Life-Health Sciences Internship Program](http://lhsi.iupui.edu/)   ### How to spot a fraudulent employer  Not all employment opportunities are legitimate. Some organizations may pose as potential employers to collect personal information from or to defraud job seekers. Here are steps you can take to verify the legitimacy of an employer:  Fraudulent companies are phishing for the unsuspecting, including you. Be aware of what you share and post online. If you feel uncomfortable or aren’t sure about certain companies or employers, talk to someone in your career center.  Bottom line, if you have any questions, talk to someone before pursuing any opportunity. If an opportunity sounds too good to be true, it probably is. If you believe you are the victim of a scam, contact your local police.  Courtesy of the National Association of Colleges and Employers.  [Courtesy of the National Association of Colleges and Employers.](http://www.naceweb.org/)

## Find answers to your questions   ### Program basics   #### Do I qualify for SIP?  To apply for SIP, you must:  Transfer students are eligible after being at IUPUI for at least one semester (must have an IUPUI GPA at time of application).  International students are eligible with an active work authorization or student visa.  Students from all majors are qualified to apply.   #### Can international students apply?  International students may apply for the Sophomore Internship Program; however, applicants must be authorized to work off campus. It's the responsibility of the student to arrange their authorization. The SIP team strongly encourages students to meet with the Office of International Affairs to discuss their options.  [Office of International Affairs](https://international.iupui.edu/index.html)   #### What kind of opportunities are available?  The internship experiences are as diverse as the locations in which they are offered. We have positions from various types of majors, which change and expand every semester. Available positions are listed via the online application when it opens each semester. Previous descriptions from former interns offer excellent insight into the types of positions we can have. These can be viewed on the showcase page.  [showcase](https://getengaged.iupui.edu/showcase/2021/internships/sophomore-internships/index.html)  Our internships are currently a mix of in-person and virtual. This varies by policies on working in person from each internship site.   #### What is an internship exactly?  An internship with SIP is a paid position in which IUPUI undergraduate students engage in relevant work experiences within a professional area of study. Interns are encouraged to apply their academic experience to real-world problems and to develop critical skills in various areas of research and professional work. The National Association of Colleges and Employers sets the baseline for the criteria and definition of an internship.  [The National Association of Colleges and Employers](http://www.naceweb.org/about-us/advocacy/position-statements/position-statement-us-internships/)   #### Is this a paid internship?  Yes! Interns are paid at least $15 per hour for up to 15 hours per week. The pay is based on a $1,200 scholarship from IUPUI at the beginning of the internship and a wage of at least $7.50 per hour during the semester from the internship site to equal the total hourly pay amount. Internship sites can pay students more per hour if they desire—and a lot do! Interns are hired as hourly workers by sites and are subject to federal and state employment laws.   #### Do I have to do anything to get my SIP scholarship?  Once students are accepted into SIP, they must verify they have started at their internship site by submitting a specific assignment through the SIP Canvas site. Once confirmed, it will disburse to their bursar account just like any other loans, grants, and scholarships from IUPUI.   #### Do you accept work-study?  We do not accept work-study students at this time. Check out community work-study jobs for off-campus employers that will accept your award.  [community work-study jobs](https://employment.iupui.edu/jobs-internships/search-job-board/index.html)   #### What are my chances of being accepted into the program?  You must meet the basic requirements and submit the application on time to be considered. We recommend you apply at your earliest opportunity (usually the spring of your first year at IUPUI) to allow another year of eligibility if you don't get in on your first try.  The most successful applicants have utilized campus career services for assistance in putting together the application materials.  [campus career services](http://career.iupui.edu/Students-Alums/Career-Services-in-Your-School)   #### I have a bachelor's degree already, but I'm coming back for pre-req classes. Am I eligible?  Unfortunately, students who are no longer in their undergraduate years are not eligible for our program. However, you may be eligible for other internship opportunities. Check with your school's career services office for more resources.  [school's career services office](https://career.iupui.edu/students-alumni/career-services/index.html)   ### Program logistics   #### How long does the internship last?  All internships with SIP are one semester long. Therefore, internships may begin in late August and end in mid-December (fall semester) or begin in early January and end in early May (spring semester). Some sites may choose to hire students under other funding after the internship ends.   #### How many hours per week would I work? When would I work?  Interns work a maximum of 15 hours per week, usually during 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. on weekdays. Check your schedule to make sure you have those hours available, preferably in a few blocks of time each week, before you apply for the program.  Hour requirements or restrictions are specified by internship sites in the job postings listed within the online application. This can also be a great interview question to ask employers!   #### Where would I be working?  All SIP internship sites are located in the off-campus Indianapolis area. We do not offer on-campus internships at this time.   #### What are the clothing requirements?  Dress code is specified within the job posting for each internship. This is available during the application period. Generally, the dress code is based on an office setting.   #### How do I apply for SIP?  The online application is available toward the beginning of the fall semester for spring internships and beginning of the spring semester for fall internships. You must complete the application in full, which includes a resume, short-answer questions, and professional references. The application must be completed by the deadline. Applications submitted after the given deadline will not be accepted.   ### Program application   #### What is the application/selection process?  Phase 1  Phase 2  Phase 3   #### When is the application deadline?  Deadlines change each semester due to internship sites changing each semester. The SIP team tries to have the application for a spring internship to be due the week before fall break; and the application for a fall internship to be due the week before spring break. The deadline will be made available on the site and within the application once it's posted for each semester.  We encourage you to submit your application at least a week before the deadline. Late applications are not accepted.   #### How do I create my best resume?  The Office of Student Employment has many helpful resources for writing a resume .  [writing a resume](https://employment.iupui.edu/events-resources/resources/resume.html)  We highly recommend you visit our office or your school's career office to check your resume and other application materials. You can visit the Learn how to apply page to learn how to meet with them.   #### Do I need to submit a cover letter?  You will not need to submit a cover letter for the application. The questions on the application will help us get to know you and prepare you for interviews. However, employers may ask for a cover letter after being matched for an interview.   #### Whom should I ask to be a reference?  Appropriate references are former supervisors, professors, academic counselors, advisors, peer leaders, or anyone who can speak to the quality of your work. They are usually happy to act as a reference, so just ask them! Inappropriate references include friends and family members. We do not ask for letters of recommendation, just contact information.   #### How do I find the SIP internship sites?  Internship sites will become available when the online application opens. Within the application, there will be a Google Sites link to view all internship site descriptions and job postings.

## Find your intern talent at IUPUI  IUPUI is your source for interns who can provide the talent your organization needs to be competitive and to grow. Located in downtown Indianapolis with over 30,000 students studying in 18 different IU and Purdue schools, your organization can find the students with the skills you are seeking. Students from IUPUI are often seeking internships year-round.   ### Posting internship positions  We are pleased to invite you to join IUPUI on Handshake , our new career services platform, which is now being utilized by all IU campuses.  [Handshake](https://iupui.joinhandshake.com/)  IUPUI’s move to Handshake makes it even easier to post to all IU campuses. When posting an internship opportunity, you will now be able to quickly select any IU campus for your positions. This new approach will continue to be enriched with support from the career services offices on IU’s campuses and schools, and it vastly simplifies employer engagement with IU. Likewise, it will make it much easier for IUPUI students to find internships for which they are qualified.  If you’d like more information, please visit the Handshake employer site or join us on Handshake . If you are a campus employer seeking to hire students, request your Handshake account here .  [Handshake employer site](https://support.joinhandshake.com/hc/en-us/categories/202707307-Employer)  [Handshake](https://iupui.joinhandshake.com/)  [here](https://iu.co1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_ezodc3Nnalb6tj7)  Need help creating an internship position or program? Contact Brian Benedict, assistant director for internships ( bbenedic@iupui.edu ), or contact a specific school's career services office directly, and we will be happy to assist you.   ### Guidelines for internships  The IUPUI Career Services Council has developed guidelines specific to the university that must be followed for recruiting and hiring students from the campus.  [guidelines](https://indiana.sharepoint.com/:b:/s/msteams_92d57a/Ea_aUmvE8lhIo2FWjLlb1uYBYrgw_HC3cQaPz-YREKvj4A?e=9raAoR)  Employers are encouraged to pay interns. If you want to post an unpaid internship, it must meet the guidelines set forth by the Fair Labor Standards Act for internship programs.  [Fair Labor Standards Act](http://www.dol.gov/whd/regs/compliance/whdfs71.htm)  When recruiting interns, employers are expected to follow the Principles for Employment Professionals set forth by the National Association of Colleges and Employers (NACE) in their recruiting and selection practices.  [Principles for Employment Professionals](https://www.naceweb.org/talent-acquisition/standards-competencies/professional-standards-for-university-relations-recruiting/)  Employers should also ensure compliance with EEOC laws that are designed to protect both the employer and student workers.  [EEOC](http://www.eeoc.gov/laws/statutes/index.cfm)  Third-party recruiters are welcome to recruit interns from IUPUI for their clients. The hiring company must be disclosed in the job posting. In addition, there must be no cost to the student for any services provided in the recruitment and placement process.

IUPUI Career Services is committed to protecting your privacy and developing technology that gives you the most powerful and safe online experience. This Statement of Privacy applies to the IUPUI Career Services Web site and governs data collection and usage. By using the IUPUI Career Services website, you consent to the data practices described in this statement.   ## Collection of your personal information  IUPUI Career Services collects personally identifiable information, such as your e-mail address, name, home or work address or telephone number. IUPUI Career Services also collects anonymous demographic information, which is not unique to you, such as your ZIP code, age, gender, preferences, interests and favorites.  There is also information about your computer hardware and software that is automatically collected by IUPUI Career Services. This information can include: your IP address, browser type, domain names, access times and referring Web site addresses. This information is used by IUPUI Career Services for the operation of the service, to maintain quality of the service, and to provide general statistics regarding use of the IUPUI Career Services Web site.  Please keep in mind that if you directly disclose personally identifiable information or personally sensitive data through IUPUI Career Services public message boards, this information may be collected and used by others. Note: IUPUI Career Services does not read any of your private online communications.  IUPUI Career Services encourages you to review the privacy statements of Web sites you choose to link to from IUPUI Career Services so that you can understand how those Web sites collect, use and share your information. IUPUI Career Services is not responsible for the privacy statements or other content on Web sites outside of the IUPUI Career Services and IUPUI Career Services family of Web sites.   ## Use of your personal information  IUPUI Career Services collects and uses your personal information to operate the IUPUI Career Services Web site and deliver the services you have requested. IUPUI Career Services also uses your personally identifiable information to inform you of other products or services available from IUPUI Career Services and its affiliates. IUPUI Career Services may also contact you via surveys to conduct research about your opinion of current services or of potential new services that may be offered.  IUPUI Career Services does not sell, rent or lease its customer lists to third parties. IUPUI Career Services may, from time to time, contact you on behalf of external business partners about a particular offering that may be of interest to you. In those cases, your unique personally identifiable information (e-mail, name, address, telephone number) is not transferred to the third party. In addition, IUPUI Career Services may share data with trusted partners to help us perform statistical analysis, send you email or postal mail, provide customer support, or arrange for deliveries. All such third parties are prohibited from using your personal information except to provide these services to IUPUI Career Services, and they are required to maintain the confidentiality of your information.  IUPUI Career Services does not use or disclose sensitive personal information, such as race, religion, or political affiliations, without your explicit consent.  IUPUI Career Services keeps track of the Web sites and pages our customers visit within IUPUI Career Services, in order to determine what IUPUI Career Services services are the most popular. This data is used to deliver customized content and advertising within IUPUI Career Services to customers whose behavior indicates that they are interested in a particular subject area.  IUPUI Career Services Web sites will disclose your personal information, without notice, only if required to do so by law or in the good faith belief that such action is necessary to: (a) conform to the edicts of the law or comply with legal process served on IUPUI Career Services or the site; (b) protect and defend the rights or property of IUPUI Career Services; and, (c) act under exigent circumstances to protect the personal safety of users of IUPUI Career Services, or the public.   ## Use of cookies  The IUPUI Career Services Web site use "cookies" to help you personalize your online experience. A cookie is a text file that is placed on your hard disk by a Web page server. Cookies cannot be used to run programs or deliver viruses to your computer. Cookies are uniquely assigned to you, and can only be read by a web server in the domain that issued the cookie to you.  One of the primary purposes of cookies is to provide a convenience feature to save you time. The purpose of a cookie is to tell the Web server that you have returned to a specific page. For example, if you personalize IUPUI Career Services pages, or register with IUPUI Career Services site or services, a cookie helps IUPUI Career Services to recall your specific information on subsequent visits. This simplifies the process of recording your personal information, such as billing addresses, shipping addresses, and so on. When you return to the same IUPUI Career Services Web site, the information you previously provided can be retrieved, so you can easily use the IUPUI Career Services features that you customized.  You have the ability to accept or decline cookies. Most Web browsers automatically accept cookies, but you can usually modify your browser setting to decline cookies if you prefer. If you choose to decline cookies, you may not be able to fully experience the interactive features of the IUPUI Career Services services or Web sites you visit.   ## Security of your personal information  IUPUI Career Services secures your personal information from unauthorized access, use or disclosure. IUPUI Career Services secures the personally identifiable information you provide on computer servers in a controlled, secure environment, protected from unauthorized access, use or disclosure. When personal information (such as a credit card number) is transmitted to other Web sites, it is protected through the use of encryption, such as the Secure Socket Layer (SSL) protocol.   ## Changes to this statement  IUPUI Career Services will occasionally update this Statement of Privacy to reflect company and customer feedback. IUPUI Career Services encourages you to periodically review this Statement to be informed of how IUPUI Career Services is protecting your information.   ## Contact information  IUPUI Career Services welcomes your comments regarding this Statement of Privacy. If you believe that IUPUI Career Services has not adhered to this Statement, please contact IUPUI Career Services at nsbyrer@iupui.edu . We will use commercially reasonable efforts to promptly determine and remedy the problem.

## Resources for career and internship search for LGBTQ+ students  Navigating the career and internship search process can be challenging. Doing so as an LGBTQ+ student can be even more so. We have compiled some of our best advice on how to manage the process below.   ### How "out" are you?  One of the most challenging things about navigating the career search as an LGBTQ+ person is determining how comfortable you are with sharing this part of yourself with an interviewing team.  In an ideal world, the fact that you are LGBTQ+ should not be a factor in the hiring process. The harsh reality is that it does matter to some people and to some companies.  Determining how much you want to share with a prospective employer about this part of yourself is up to you and might change throughout the process. It is common for LGBTQ+ people to vary their levels of outness with coworkers, families, and friends. You may be more open in your friend circle and more private in the workplace, which happens frequently.  Hiding your identity may cause you to feel frustrated about leading a dual life and lower your self-esteem. However, being open about your sexuality might lead to discrimination, harassment, or loss of employment. No one can determine how much of yourself you should share except you. Talk with your career counselor or another trusted person to figure out what you are comfortable with.   ### Finding inclusive companies  Figuring out if a company is welcoming to LGBTQ+ people can be a challenge. Here are some ways you can gather information to make your decision:  Do your research  Visit the company website and social media to find the answers to these questions:  Find someone who works at the company that is LGBTQ+ and ask them for some of their time to talk about the environment. Possible questions you can ask them include:  Visit the Human Rights Campaign (HRC) website and view the results of their most recent Corporate Equality Index (CEI) . This is a helpful tool that will show you how more than 1,000 companies rank in the areas of policies, practices, and benefits for their LGBTQ+ employees.  [Corporate Equality Index (CEI)](https://www.hrc.org/resources/corporate-equality-index)  Review the list of companies listed on any local LGBTQ+ Chamber of Commerce websites. For the Indianapolis area, you should refer to the Indy Rainbow Chamber website.  [Indy Rainbow Chamber](https://www.indyrainbowchamber.org/directory)  It is difficult to determine if a company will be welcoming to you, however, finding out the above information can help you to make your decision.   ### Resumes  Every employer expects to see something different on a resume. If you asked 30 recruiters what they need on a resume, you would most likely get 30 different answers.  Our best resume advice is to speak with a career counselor in your school. There are pieces of information you will want to include that are specific to your major, and the best way to find those out is to speak with someone in your school. To see who you should talk to in your school, visit here .  When you are designing your resume as an LGBTQ+ student, there are some things you should consider:  Legal name  When listing your name on your resume, you should write the name that you want to be called. When you are completing an official job application or background check forms, you should list your legal name even if it is different than the name you listed on your resume. Sometimes you will be able to put your preferred or chosen name in parenthesis on those documents and follow up with the employer during the interview process to explain why the listed names are different. Talk to your career counselor or another trusted person if you would like to practice this conversation in advance.  LGBTQ+ student group involvement  Some say that you should not list anything on your resume that might have the potential to be used against you in the hiring process. Others say that if an employer takes issue with these parts of you then you do not want to work there anyway. You should consider all of these points and trust your own judgement while navigating the process.  Some people are comfortable with listing their queer extracurricular activities on their resume with the full name of the student organization. Others might want to label the student organization as an "anti-discrimination organization." A third option would be to omit the organization all together. All of these are valid choices. Only you can decide how much you want to share.   ### Interviewing  When it is time for you to start interviewing for full-time or internship positions, the best thing you can do to prepare is to complete a mock interview with your career counselor. These interactive experiences allow you to practice what you are going to say and to find some common interviewing questions. To find out who your career counselor is, visit here .  Navigating the interview process as an LGBTQ+ student can be challenging and rewarding. Consider these tips:  Attire  Dress for the job you want. This is an old theory that still holds true. No matter what your gender identity is, you should dress for the job you want. This means business professional attire should be worn for interviews. It does not matter if you wear pants or a skirt, it only matters that you are professional and confident. If you have questions about how to navigate this, please visit with a career counselor.  Interview the interviewer  Interviewing is a two-way street. Not only are they interviewing you to determine your skills and fit with the organization, you should be interviewing them too. You will want to make sure that this is a company you want to spend 40 hours a week at. There are questions you can ask during the interview process that can help you determine if they provide a welcoming environment.  It is sometimes helpful to ask multiple people the same question to see if you get the same answer. This will help you determine if they are answering truthfully or just saying what you want to hear.  These should not be your first questions during an interview. Focus on the job and your capabilities first. Make the company want to hire you. After you have convinced them you are the right one for the job, then make inquiries about policies regarding LGBTQ+ issues.  Onsite observations  Once you are invited to do an in-person interview, you will be able to pick up on some clues as well. Things you might look for during an interview include:  None of these observations by themselves will give you a full picture, but they can be considered along with other information you gather to determine if this is a good fit for you.  Questions they should not ask  Some of these questions are illegal and some show the negative character of a company. If you asked questions like this, consider responding by asking them how this is relevant to my ability to perform this job.   ### Onboarding  Congratulations! You have successfully navigated the hiring process, and now it is time to begin your career or internship!  Some people find it difficult to share their full selves at work. That is normal. According to the Human Right Campaign (HRC) , there are lots of reasons why people may not disclose their sexuality or gender identity in the workplace including:  [Human Right Campaign (HRC)](https://www.hrc.org/news/hrc-report-startling-data-reveals-half-of-lgbtq-employees-in-us-remain-clos)  Only you can determine how "out" you want to be. Finding like-minded peers will help you feel included and joining or starting an employee resource or affinity group will help you connect with other LGBTQ+ people and allies, which can help you transition into being a full-time employee authentically.

## Handshake Management  IUPUI has recently joined Handshake as the campus career services management system for the campus. The IUPUI Handshake system is managed by career services professionals in the participating schools and offices on campus.  As a campus, we are currently developing a memorandum of understanding (MOU) regarding the management of our Handshake system. Should you have questions about the management of Handshake, please reach out to Campus Career and Advising Services ( ccas@iupui.edu ).

## If you're unsure where to start . . .  As a first point of contact, Campus Career and Advising Services (CCAS) can assist business, industry, government, and nonprofit organizations in accessing campus career resources. CCAS can help you develop internships and partnerships with students and school representatives. If you're hiring an intern for the first time or if you’re unsure which academic department will fit your needs, contact CCAS at ccas@iupui.edu or 317-274-3595.  [Campus Career and Advising Services](https://ccas.iupui.edu/)   ### Post a position  Learn more about IUPUI Talent to post job or internship opportunities for all IUPUI students and alumni.   ### Internships  Get information and resources for creating and posting internships to recruit IUPUI students.   ### Recruit in a specific school or academic area  Many departments on campus provide recruiting services to employers wishing to hire their students for professional jobs and internship opportunities, including on-campus recruiting, job and internship fairs, cooperative education programs, job and internship databases, and resume referrals. Contact the career services office of your choice using the school-specific career services . Contact the career services office of your choice using the school-specific career services .  [school-specific career services](https://career.iupui.edu/employers/school-specific-career-offices/index.html)   ### Community Work-Study Program  Community Work-Study provides the opportunity for nonprofit and government agencies to recruit and to hire IUPUI students who qualify for Federal Work-Study as employees and interns. These part-time employment opportunities provide college students with educationally relevant work experience while making a difference in the community. Nonprofit and government agencies that qualify to become work-study agencies are responsible for paying 25% of a student's wages, while Federal Work-Study pays the other 75%. For agencies interested in becoming a work-study approved agency, contact the Office of Student Employment via email fwsjobs@iupui.edu or call (317) 274-0857.
